para.paratext: Both Fed. R. Evid. 611(a) and O.C.G.A. § 24-6-611 give courts broad discretion over the mode and order of interrogating witnesses. The court may allow witnesses to respond to specific questions, general questions, leading questions, or testify in a narrative form. A leading question is one so framed as to suggest the desired answer.[1]

Generally, leading questions are proper only during cross-examination, but the court may grant or withhold this form of questioning during direct[2] or cross-examination when the conduct of the witness or justice shall require it. Both federal and state courts allow parties to expedite a trial by asking leading questions on direct examination on undisputed, preliminary, or collateral matters.[3] Also, at the court's discretion, a party may use leading questions to examine an adverse party or one identified with an adverse party.[4]

In Bell v. State,[5] the Georgia Court of Appeals affirmed that the trial court acted within its discretion by allowing a prosecutor to use leading questions during direct examination of a child victim. The victim was 14 years old at the time of trial, was often unresponsive, spoke very quietly, and exhibited signs of timidity or fear.

This discretion extends to allowing leading questions on direct of witnesses who are nervous, ignorant, or hostile.[6] In Mercer v. Woodard,[7] the court properly forced a defendant to ask direct examination questions of a plaintiff whom it called as a witness during presentation of the defense case and properly allowed plaintiff's counsel to ask leading questions.
In Dumas v. State,[8] the court allowed leading questions on direct for a witness who had difficulty speaking English.

Since the purpose of redirect examination is to elicit evidence which explains, refutes or qualifies matters raised during cross-examination, both Georgia and federal courts allow leading questions as a necessary tool to direct the witness' attention to the exact subject matter of the testimony sought.[9]

O.C.G.A. § 24-6-611 guarantees, “the right of a thorough and sifting cross-examination shall belong to every party as to the witnesses called against him. If several parties to the same case have distinct interests, each may exercise this right.” Although federal courts and many state courts limit the scope of cross-examination to issues addressed on direct examination or affecting the credibility of the witness,[10] Georgia has retained its “free” common-law based rule regarding the scope of cross-examination.[11] Under the free rule, a party may cross-examine witness about any subject relevant to any issue in the case, including facts relating solely to the examiner's case or affirmative defense.[12] The trial court has broad discretion to curtail the extent of cross-examination if the inquiry is not relevant.[13] “Like most questions about the admissibility of evidence, the scope of cross-examination is committed in the first instance to the sound discretion of the trial court, and … a limitation of cross-examination [is reviewed] only for an abuse of that discretion.”[14] Moreover, O.C.G.A. § 24-6-611(a) gives the trial court reasonable control over the mode and order of interrogating witnesses. In Jordan v. State,[15] the Court of Appeals refused to find an abuse of discretion where the defense called the victim to testify during its case-in-chief and the trial court denied the request because the victim had testified for the prosecution and was thoroughly cross-examined by defense counsel at that time.

Also, both federal and Georgia courts must protect a witness from harsh or unfair treatment by counsel.[16] In Loomis v. State,[17] the court properly admonished defendant's counsel for speaking too loudly when he questioned a 12-year-old witness. In Elkins v. State,[18] the court allowed a juvenile witness to break for the evening over objection. The Court of Appeals found it was proper, given the court's reasoning that it was past the time the jurors should have been dismissed for the evening, and because the witness stated he needed a break.

In Butler v. State,[19] the court sustained the state's objection of the defense counsel's fourth question to a witness regarding whether he would tell a lie when the witness had answered “no” to the previous three questions.

Counsel who called the witness has a duty to protect the witness with proper and timely objections under O.C.G.A. §§ 24-6-623 and 24-6-611, but this duty must be balanced against the parties' right to a thorough and sifting cross-examination.[20] The court may not limit the cross-examination of a witness to matters elicited on direct examination[21] nor may the court deny a party cross-examination entirely.[22]

In Druitt v. State,[23] the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the trial court's refusal to permit a driving under the influence (DUI) defendant to require a police officer to demonstrate the “one-leg stand” test on cross-examination because the officer's ability to perform the test was not relevant to a determination of whether the defendant had been driving while impaired.

If relevant, a party may cross-examine the opposing party based upon that party's unsworn pleadings.[24] In Davis v. State,[25] the court ruled that the defense had no right to cross-examine an investigating officer, after the state introduced the officer's report, regarding a statement made by defendant contained within his report.

The biases, prejudices, or ulterior motives of a witness are always a proper subject of cross-examination. In Hurston v. State,[26] the Georgia Court of Appeals reversed the defendant's conviction because the trial court did not allow him to cross-examine the state's key witness about criminal charges pending against him. However, the Georgia Supreme Court upheld a conviction where the trial court prohibited the defense from cross-examining a witness regarding his immigration status.[27]
Under the new Code, any party may impeach the credibility of a witness regardless of who called him.[28]

A party may call an opposing lawyer to the witness stand for cross-examination if he does not offer proof to support his claims about a witness. In U.S. v. Pugliese,[29] a lawyer asked a witness if she had been hospitalized for mental problems, but then offered no proof to support the question when she denied that she had been. Judge Learned Hand held that the court properly allowed the opposing party to call this lawyer to the stand for cross-examination.

A party may waive cross-examination of a witness expressly or by failing to object to a ruling of the court.[30] If a witness testifies on direct examination but is unable to continue through cross examination, then the court may strike the witness' direct testimony or declare a mistrial. In Gale v. State,[31] a witness testified on direct, but then collapsed before she could be cross-examined. The defendant declined the court's offer to declare a mistrial and moved to strike the witness' direct testimony. The court denied the motion, but the defendant failed to object, thereby waiving his right to cross-examination. Often this situation arises when a witness claims his privilege against self-incrimination and refuses to answer a question on cross-examination. If a witness' claim of privilege on cross-examination prevents inquiry into the details of his direct examination testimony, then the court should strike the witness' direct examination testimony in whole or in part.[32]

With Georgia's adoption of the federal rule in O.C.G.A. § 24-7-705, an expert witness does not need to be questioned using hypothetical questions. However, if counsel chooses to use a hypothetical question, then it must be based on evidence used at trial.
Ealey v. State, 139 Ga. App. 110, 227 S.E.2d 902 (1976).
The appellate court rarely interferes with the trial court's discretion in this matter. Daniels v. State, 230 Ga. 126, 195 S.E.2d 900 (1973).
Shirley v. State, 148 Ga. App. 96, 97, 251 S.E.2d 57 (1978).
Jaffe v. Bank of America, N.A., 395 Fed. Appx. 583, 588 (11th Cir. 2010).
Bell v. State, 294 Ga. App. 779, 670 S.E.2d 476 (2008).
Fugate v. State, 263 Ga. 260, 431 S.E.2d 104 (1993). See also Dumas v. State, 283 Ga. App. 279, 641 S.E.2d 271 (2007).
Mercer v. Woodard, 166 Ga. App. 119, 303 S.E.2d 475 (1983). The defense had already cross-examined the plaintiff during the plaintiff's case.
In Dumas v. State, 283 Ga. App. 279, 641 S.E.2d 271 (2007), the court reporter stated that she was “slightly confident” that she understood the witness.
Brown v. State, 203 Ga. 218, 46 S.E.2d 160 (1948); Wright and Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure, Evidence § 6552.

Fed. R. Evid. 611(b) provides that cross-examination “shall be limited to the subject matter of the direct examination and matters affecting the credibility of the witness.” The court does retain the discretion to allow a party to inquire into additional matters, but must proceed as if on direct examination. Many district courts have been reversed for unduly limiting the scope of cross-examination. See U.S. v. Segal, 534 F.2d 578, 2 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 542 (3d Cir. 1976); U.S. v. Callahan, 551 F.2d 733, 1 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 881 (6th Cir. 1977); U.S. v. Wolfson, 573 F.2d 216, 45 A.L.R. Fed. 625 (5th Cir. 1978); U.S. v. Jackson, 576 F.2d 46 (5th Cir. 1978).

Ficken v. City of Atlanta, 114 Ga. 970, 41 S.E. 58 (1902); Georgia Kraft Co., Woodkraft Div. v. Laborers' Intern. Union of North America, Local Union 246 (AFL-CIO), 170 Ga. App. 581, 317 S.E.2d 602 (1984).
Cowart v. Strickland, 149 Ga. 397, 100 S.E. 447, 7 A.L.R. 1110 (1919); First Nat. Bank of Birmingham v. Carmichael, 198 Ga. 309, 31 S.E.2d 811 (1944).

The Georgia Court of Appeals will not overturn the trial court's decision unless it manifestly abused its discretion. See, e.g., Hibbard v. McMillan, 284 Ga. App. 753, 645 S.E.2d 356 (2007); Lawton v. State, 281 Ga. 459, 640 S.E.2d 14 (2007).
Jordan v. State, 344 Ga. App. 267, 810 S.E.2d 158 (2018).
O.C.G.A. § 24-6-611(a)(3) and Fed. R. Evid. 611(a) both provide that in exercising its control over the proceedings, the court shall protect witnesses from “harassment or undue embarrassment.”
Loomis v. State, 78 Ga. App. 336, 51 S.E.2d 33 (1948); Schneider v. State, 267 Ga. App. 508, 603 S.E.2d 663 (2004).
Elkins v. State, 2019 WL 2710085 (Ga. 2019).
Butler v. State, 285 Ga. 518, 678 S.E.2d 92 (2009).
Palmer v. Taylor, 215 Ga. App. 546, 451 S.E.2d 486 (1994).

In Anderson v. Anderson, 238 Ga. 631, 235 S.E.2d 11 (1977), the court erroneously decided a custody issue based on a report to which neither party had access, thereby denying them the right of cross-examination of the witnesses against them.
Thomas v. Clark, 188 Ga. App. 606, 373 S.E.2d 668 (1988).
Hurston v. State, 206 Ga. App. 570, 426 S.E.2d 196 (1992).
U.S. v. Pugliese, 153 F.2d 497 (C.C.A. 2d Cir. 1945).
Benton Rapid Exp. v. Sammons, 63 Ga. App. 23, 10 S.E.2d 290 (1940).
Smith v. State, 225 Ga. 328, 168 S.E.2d 587 (1969). The court applied the Smith case in Hubbard v. State, 173 Ga. App. 127, 325 S.E.2d 799 (1984), in which the entire direct testimony was stricken.
See also Emmett v. State, 232 Ga. 110, 205 S.E.2d 231 (1974); Brown v. State, 139 Ga. App. 466, 228 S.E.2d 602 (1976).
